Documentation

  • High-Level API
    • Overview
    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Pipeline
      • a) Tabular Dataset
      • b) Image Dataset
    • 2. Experiment
      • Model Functions
        • fn_build
        • fn_train
      • Hyperparameters
      • Experiment.make()
  • Low-Level API
    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Ingest a Dataset
      • Object Relational Model (ORM)
      • Persisting and Compressing Structured Data
      • Data Sources
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_pandas()
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_numpy()
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_path
        • Image Datasets
        • Dataset.Image.from_urls()
        • Dataset.Image.from_folder()
      • Reading Datasets
      • Dataset.Tabular.to_pandas()
      • Dataset.Tabular.to_numpy()
      • Dataset.Image.to_pillow()
      • Dataset.Image.to_numpy()
    • 2. Select the Label column(s).
      • ORM
      • Deriving Labels
      • Reading Labels
    • 3. Select the Featureset column(s).
      • ORM
      • Deriving Labels
      • Reading Featuresets
    • 4. Slice samples with a Splitset.
      • Split Strategies
        • a) Default supervised 70-30 split.
        • b) Specifying test size.
        • c) Specifying validation size.
        • d) Taking the whole dataset as a training split.
        • e) Stratification of continuous labels.
      • Reading Splitsets
      • Splitset.to_numpy()
      • Splitset.to_pandas()
    • 5. Optionally, create a Foldset for cross-validation.
      • ORM
        • Fold objects
      • Deriving Foldsets
      • Reading Foldsets
      • Foldset.to_numpy()
      • Foldset.to_pandas()
    • 6. Optionally, stage an Encoderset for encoding.
      • Background
    • 7. Optionally, set a single Labelcoder.
      • Background
    • 8. Optionally, determine a sequence of Featurecoder(s).
      • Background
      • Filtering feature columns
    • 9. Create an Algorithm aka model.
      • ORM
      • Model Definition
        • Function to build model
        • Optional, function to calculate loss.
        • Optional, function to optimize model.
        • Function to train model
        • Optional, function to predict samples
        • Group the functions together in an Algorithm!
    • 8. Optional, associate a Hyperparamset with your model.
    • 9. Create a Queue of training Jobs.
      • Job objects.
      • Execute all Jobs.
        • 1. queue.run_jobs(in_background=False)
        • 2. queue.run_jobs(in_background=True); experimental
        • 3. Future, distributed cloud execution.
        • Job.fitted_encoders
    • 10. Assess the Results.
      • Fetching the trained model.
      • Fetching metrics.
    • 11. Metrics & Visualization
  • Visualization & Metrics

Visualization & MetricsÂ¶

PrerequisitesÂ¶

Plotly is used for all charts to provide an interactive experience: hover, toggle, and zoom. Reference the Installation notebook for information about configuring Plotly. However, static images are used in this notebook due to recent difficulty with 3rd party JS on the documentation portal.

OverviewÂ¶

As described in the Low-Level Docs, the Result(s) of each training Job are automatically populated with metrics for each split/ fold of samples evaluated against the model. The Algorithm.analysis_type determines which metrics and plots are prepared:

  • Although 'classification_multi' and 'classification_binary' share the same metrics and plots, they go about producing these artifacts differently. For example, ROC curves roc_multi_class=None vs roc_multi_class='ovr'.

  • 'regression', unlike the classification analyses, does not have an â€˜accuracyâ€™ metric, so we substitute â€˜r2â€™, R^2 (coefficient of determination, for it. There are no regression-specific plots.

Weâ€™ll use the datum and tests modules to rapidly create some examples.

[2]:

import aiqc
from aiqc import datum
from aiqc import tests

ClassificationÂ¶

[3]:

queue_multiclass = tests.make_test_queue('keras_multiclass')


___/ featurecoder_index: 0 \_________

=> The column(s) below matched your filter(s) and were ran through a test-encoding successfully.
['petal_width']

=> The remaining column(s) and dtype(s) can be used in downstream Featurecoder(s):
{'petal_length': 'float64', 'sepal_length': 'float64', 'sepal_width': 'float64'}


___/ featurecoder_index: 1 \_________

=> The column(s) below matched your filter(s) and were ran through a test-encoding successfully.
['sepal_length', 'sepal_width', 'petal_length']

=> Nice! Now all feature column(s) have encoder(s) associated with them.
No more Featurecoders can be added to this Encoderset.


[6]:

queue_multiclass.run_jobs()

ðŸ”® Training Models ðŸ”®: 100%|â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ| 8/8 [00:30<00:00,  3.87s/it]

Individual Job MetricsÂ¶

Each training Result contains the following metrics.

[7]:

from pprint import pprint as p
p(
    queue_multiclass.jobs[0].results[0].metrics
)

{'test': {'accuracy': 0.9629629629629629,
          'f1': 0.9628482972136223,
          'loss': 0.07572123408317566,
          'precision': 0.9666666666666667,
          'recall': 0.9629629629629629,
          'roc_auc': 1.0},
 'train': {'accuracy': 0.9803921568627451,
           'f1': 0.9803921568627451,
           'loss': 0.07449501752853394,
           'precision': 0.9803921568627451,
           'recall': 0.9803921568627451,
           'roc_auc': 0.9988465974625144},
 'validation': {'accuracy': 1.0,
                'f1': 1.0,
                'loss': 0.10631509870290756,
                'precision': 1.0,
                'recall': 1.0,
                'roc_auc': 1.0}}

It also contains per-epoch History metrics calculated during model training.

[8]:

queue_multiclass.jobs[0].results[0].history.keys()

[8]:

dict_keys(['loss', 'accuracy', 'val_loss', 'val_accuracy'])

Aggregate Queue MetricsÂ¶

  • selected_metrics:list - If you get overwhelmed by the variety of metrics returned, then you can include the ones you want selectively by name.

  • sort_by:str - You can sort the dataframe by any column name.

  • ascending:bool=False - Descending if False.

[9]:

queue_multiclass.metrics_to_pandas(
    selected_metrics=None
    , sort_by=None
    , ascending=False
)

[9]:

Aggregate Queue VisualizationÂ¶

plot_performance aka the â€œboomerang chartâ€ is unique to AIQC, and it really brings the benefits of the library to light. Each model from the Queue is evaluated against all splits/ folds.

When performing classification, the secondary training metric (non-loss) is â€˜accuracyâ€™.

[ ]:

queue_multiclass.plot_performance(
    max_loss = 1.0, min_accuracy = 0.80
)

Individual Job VisualizationÂ¶

Loss values in the first few epochs can often be extremely high before they plummet and become more gradual. This really stretches out the graph and makes it hard to see if the evaluation set is diverging or not. The loss_skip_15pct:bool parameter skips displaying the first 15% of epochs so that figure is more useful.

[ ]:

queue_multiclass.jobs[0].results[0].plot_learning_curve(loss_skip_15pct=True)

These classification metrics are preformatted for plotting.

[13]:

queue_multiclass.jobs[0].results[0].plot_data['test'].keys()

[13]:

dict_keys(['confusion_matrix', 'roc_curve', 'precision_recall_curve'])

[ ]:

queue_multiclass.jobs[0].results[0].plot_roc_curve()


[ ]:

queue_multiclass.jobs[0].results[0].plot_confusion_matrix()


[ ]:

queue_multiclass.jobs[0].results[0].plot_precision_recall()

RegressionÂ¶

[17]:

queue_regression = tests.make_test_queue('keras_regression')


___/ featurecoder_index: 0 \_________

=> The column(s) below matched your filter(s) and were ran through a test-encoding successfully.
['crim', 'zn', 'indus', 'nox', 'rm', 'age', 'dis', 'ptratio', 'lstat']

=> The remaining column(s) and dtype(s) can be used in downstream Featurecoder(s):
{'chas': 'int64', 'rad': 'int64', 'tax': 'int64'}


___/ featurecoder_index: 1 \_________

=> The column(s) below matched your filter(s) and were ran through a test-encoding successfully.
['rad', 'chas', 'tax']

=> Nice! Now all feature column(s) have encoder(s) associated with them.
No more Featurecoders can be added to this Encoderset.


[18]:

queue_regression.run_jobs()

ðŸ”® Training Models ðŸ”®: 100%|â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ| 4/4 [00:33<00:00,  8.31s/it]

Individual Job MetricsÂ¶

Each training Result contains the following metrics.

[19]:

from pprint import pprint as p
p(
    queue_regression.jobs[0].results[0].metrics
)

{'test': {'explained_variance': 0.7456242137896081,
          'loss': 0.2185862511396408,
          'mse': 0.21858626188755587,
          'r2': 0.7455021802201329},
 'train': {'explained_variance': 0.7981549758441983,
           'loss': 0.20313556492328644,
           'mse': 0.20313555856135915,
           'r2': 0.7968644414386409},
 'validation': {'explained_variance': 0.8418251849670012,
                'loss': 0.1677088737487793,
                'mse': 0.16770889185282173,
                'r2': 0.8384872353457703}}

It also contains per-epoch metrics calculated during model training.

[20]:

queue_regression.jobs[0].results[0].history.keys()

[20]:

dict_keys(['loss', 'mean_squared_error', 'val_loss', 'val_mean_squared_error'])

Aggregate Queue VisualizationÂ¶

When performing regression, the secondary training metric (non-loss) is â€˜r2â€™.

[ ]:

queue_regression.plot_performance(
    max_loss=1.0, min_r2=0.60
)

Individual Job VisualizationÂ¶

[ ]:

queue_regression.jobs[0].results[0].plot_learning_curve(loss_skip_15pct=True)
